Exclusive

Honkers & Associates Announces "Project Skyward Honk": First Goose in Orbit by Q3

By Margaret Featherstone, Senior Aerospace Correspondent · Feb 10, 2026

In a move that stunned both the aerospace industry and the ornithological community, Honkers & Associates CEO Gerald Honksworth III unveiled the company's most ambitious initiative to date: a fully goose-operated space program with a projected budget of $4.7 million and "whatever bread we find on the way."

"The humans had their chance," Honksworth declared at this morning's press conference, reading from a crumpled piece of construction paper in red crayon. "They went to the moon and did what? Planted a flag? We're going to plant a flag AND a decoy owl. That's called strategy."

The rocket, designated HK-1 "The Big Honk," will be constructed primarily from materials sourced from the Pond District industrial zone, including reclaimed aluminum, artisanal rivets, and "a really good stick Gerald found." Engineering documents â€” all 347 pages, in Crayola's 'Macaroni and Cheese' shade â€” were submitted to the FAA on Monday.

When asked about safety protocols, Chief Engineer Beatrice Wingman (a Canada goose with 14 years of V-formation leadership experience) stated: "We've run the numbers. The numbers are in crayon, but they're still numbers."

NASA has declined to comment, though an unnamed source described the filing as "technically not illegal" and "the most colorful submission we've ever received."

Space Program Updates
Engineering

FAA Returns 347-Page Crayon Filing, Asks "Is This a Joke?" Honksworth: "The Joke Is Your Lack of Vision"

By David Gosling · Feb 9, 2026

The Federal Aviation Administration returned the entirety of Honkers & Associates' orbital launch application on Tuesday, citing concerns that "technical schematics drawn in Burnt Sienna crayon on manila paper do not meet federal documentation standards." Gerald Honksworth III called the decision "a hate crime against creativity" and immediately resubmitted the documents in Cerulean Blue.

Personnel

Astronaut Selection: 340 Geese Apply, Only 12 Can Fit in the Rocket, Gerald Insists He Gets Window Seat

By Patricia Plumage · Feb 8, 2026

The selection process has been described as "rigorous," though critics note the primary qualification appears to be "willingness to sit in a tin can" and "not biting Gerald during the interview." Three candidates were disqualified for hissing at the flight simulator. Gerald Honksworth remains automatically qualified as mission commander despite failing the physical ("I'm big-boned").

Investigation

Where Is the $4.7 Million? A Forensic Analysis of the Bread-Based Economy

By Accounting Dept. (via crayon) · Feb 7, 2026

An internal audit has revealed that approximately $1.2 million of the Series Bread funding has been spent on actual bread. Another $800,000 was allocated to "pond maintenance and emotional support pebbles." The remaining $2.7 million is technically accounted for, though the spreadsheet is in green crayon on the back of a Denny's placemat. CFO Helen Downsworth insists this is "industry standard."

Safety

Test Flight #7 Ends in Pond. Again. "That's Called a Water Landing," Says Gerald

By Safety Board (reluctantly) · Feb 6, 2026

The seventh unmanned test of the HK-1 prototype ended, like its six predecessors, in the retention pond behind the Honkers & Associates headquarters. Flight duration: 4.2 seconds. Maximum altitude: 11 feet. Gerald has classified all seven tests as "successful water landings" and awarded the engineering team a commendation in purple crayon.

"Ink is for cowards and accountants. Crayon is for visionaries, astronauts, and me. I am all three." â€” Gerald Honksworth III, CEO, from the company's IPO filing (Crayola 'Jungle Green' on butcher paper)

Corporate Desk
Quarterly Report

Q4 Earnings: Revenue Up 340%, Source of Revenue "Unclear," CFO Shrugs Visibly

By The Numbers Desk (crayon division) · Feb 5, 2026

Honkers & Associates reported record Q4 earnings of $14.2 million, up from $3.1 million in Q3. When pressed on the revenue source, CFO Helen Downsworth gestured vaguely at a whiteboard covered in green crayon and said, "Consulting." The whiteboard contained no words, only a drawing of a very large pond with dollar signs in it.

Investor confidence remains high. "I don't understand their business model," said venture capitalist Marcus Chen, "but the crayon presentations have a certain... conviction."

The earnings report itself is 84 pages long, rendered in alternating Scarlet and Periwinkle crayon. Page 47 is just a drawing of Gerald wearing a top hat. It has been submitted to the SEC, who responded with a six-word email: "Please stop sending us crayon documents."

HR Memo

Mandatory V-Formation Trust Falls Reinstated After "Incident"

By HR Dept. · Feb 4, 2026

Following what management refers to as "The February Incident" (details classified, crayon-redacted), all employees are now required to participate in weekly V-formation trust falls. Participation is mandatory. Enthusiasm is also mandatory.

"Some of you are not falling correctly," read the all-hands memo, written in Dandelion Yellow. "You know who you are. The ouija board also knows who you are."

Legal

Judge Rules Crayon Contracts "Technically Enforceable" in Delaware

By Legal Desk · Feb 3, 2026

In a landmark ruling, Delaware Superior Court Judge Patricia Malloy ruled that contracts written in crayon are legally binding, provided they are "legible and not drawn on a napkin." The Honkers legal team celebrated by issuing a 200-page crayon brief arguing that napkins should also count.

Opinion & Letters

EDITORIAL: Ink Is a Crutch and You're All Addicted

By Gerald Honksworth III, CEO · Opinion

I'm going to say what everyone is thinking but no one has the wingspan to admit: ink is a scam. A racket. Big Ink has had this industry in a chokehold since Gutenberg, and for what? So your words can look "professional"? So your contracts can be "legible from more than two feet away"?

When I founded this company in 1987 â€” in a pond, with nothing but a dream and a 12-pack of Crayolas â€” I made a vow. Every document, every memo, every legally binding orbital launch application would be written by wing, in crayon. People laughed. The FAA laughed. My own mother laughed (she was also a goose, so it sounded more like honking, but the intent was clear).

But look at us now. $14.2 million in revenue. 23 trained astronauts. A rocket that has landed in water seven times (NASA wishes they had that consistency). And every single document in our 4,812-page filing system is in crayon. Try that with your precious ink.

Ink fades. Ink smudges. Ink says "I'm afraid of color." Crayon says "I am a goose, and I am going to space, and you will read my Burnt Sienna launch protocols whether you like it or not."

The future is waxy, and it is ours.

OP-ED: I Was Abducted by the Honkers Space Program and All I Got Was This Crayon

By Kevin (intern, human) · Opinion

I was hired as a "digital communications intern." My job, I was told, would involve "social media and light transcription." What they did not mention is that all transcription is from crayon, the social media account only posts the word "HONK" in varying caps, and the office is a pond.

I have been here for nine months. I am not allowed to use pens. My desk is a lily pad. Gerald bit my sandwich on Tuesday and HR said it was "a leadership technique." I am writing this on my lunch break, which Gerald also bit.

Letters to the Editor
From: Deborah Wingfield, Concerned Shareholder
"I invested $40,000 in this company and the quarterly report was a drawing of a pond with dollar signs in it. Is this normal?"
Ed. note: Yes. Next question.
From: The Ducks at Henderson Pond
"We wish to formally object to being called 'discount geese' in your February 3rd issue. We are a proud species with our own consulting firm (DuckLogic Inc.)."
Ed. note: DuckLogic Inc. does not have a space program. Argument invalid.
From: FAA Office of Commercial Space, Washington D.C.
"Please stop submitting launch applications in crayon. This is the fourth time this month. We are begging you."
Ed. note: Forwarded to Complaints Department (ouija board). The spirits say: no.
From: Kevin's Mom
"Kevin says he's working at a pond? He has a communications degree. Please send him home."
Ed. note: Kevin is vital to operations. He is the only one with thumbs.

Corrections & Retractions

  • In our Feb 3 issue, we stated ducks are "discount geese." We stand by this assessment but acknowledge it was rude. The ouija board says we do not need to apologize.
  • The crayon color listed as "Burnt Sienna" in last week's masthead was actually "Raw Sienna." We have fired the intern responsible. (Kevin has been rehired. He is the only one with thumbs.)
  • We incorrectly reported the HK-1 reached an altitude of 15 feet during Test Flight #5. The actual altitude was 11 feet. Gerald's claim of "basically the stratosphere" has been noted.
  • Last week's weather forecast predicted "sunny with a chance of launch." It was cloudy. The rocket also did not launch. We apologize for the accuracy of neither.
  • A classified ad in our Feb 1 issue offered "gently used gravity" for $300. This was a misprint. The gravity was not gentle.
